{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3489006,"name":"Michael","username":"Mike_739","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_739/{size}/251101_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T17:10:58.860Z","cooked":"

Hello, this year I volunteered to make the bumpers for our robot, but I’m not sure what wood should be used this year. Usually, we used whatever big ¾” wood we had on hand, but this year, I want to use better wood. I was not sure if we should go with Baltic birch plywood like everyone recommends or if we should just use normal plywood. This year, we are going to two regionals as well as using a single bumper with an interchangeable fabric covering. What would be the best option for these given circumstances? Thanks! - M

Baltic birch is always better than plywood, but iirc we used regular ply last season without difficulty.

You can check out Andymark’s recommendations, they seem likely to work well.

Mike_739:

interchangeable fabric covering

I’d avoid interchangeable fabrics, especially with the new bumper rules. A second set will last longer, and swapping in pits isn’t too difficult with some of the mount designs available. I have not heard a convincing argument for the added complexity of reversible bumpers, especially when there is no longer a combined bumper weight.

Reconsider; regular ply with two bumpers will likely last longer than baltic birch with only one bumper.

Look for the plywood with the most layers, usually about 7 for 3/4". Also look for an absence of voids and knotholes in the outer layers and on inner layers along the edges. The naturally occurring defects are patched on inner and outer layers with an “eye-shaped” piece in the higher quality plywood.

The cheaper grades of plywood generally have fewer layers. The layers are cut from lower quality wood that is likely to be weaker and often have knotholes and other defects. The defects will not be patched in the lower quality plywood. The lower quality plywood typically does not hold screws as well.

My take: wood choice is only important if you aren’t doing a good job of backing your bumpers with the robot frame.

We have successfully used plain old 1x6 pine for the past several years.

Baltic is much stronger than regular plywood, but you may or may not need it depending on your weight, driving style, frame constructing etc. Baltic is also significantly heavier. Reefscape should have a lot fewer high speed collisions than previous years so that should reduce the damage. If you don’t choose Baltic make sure you are getting a structural plywood not cabinet grade, and get as may layers as possible etc.

philso:

Look for the plywood with the most layers, usually about 7 for 3/4"

Lots of layers are one of the reasons people recomend Baltic birch. 18mm (3/4") Baltic birch plywood must be 13ply, anything less and you are not buying Baltic birch. BS1088 also typically has 13 layers though it can vary by manufacturer.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T21:21:37.909Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":294,"readers_count":293,"score":103.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482895,"topic_slug":"best-bumper-wood","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-bumper-wood/482895/5","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3489290,"name":"Stephen Ostermiller","username":"stephen.ostermiller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stephen.ostermiller/{size}/188076_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T22:20:14.212Z","cooked":"

The rules allow for solid wood this year. That is going to be stronger than plywood. Find a solid wood available in your area that strikes a balance between strength, weight, and price.

If you are going to get something that is available at your typical hardware store, poplar would be a decent choice. A 1x6 poplar board would meet specifications. It is 3/4" thick and 5.5" tall. You could remove 1" from the height if desired. Such a board is usually around $4 USD per foot. So you might spend $100 in bumper wood for a pair of bumpers for a typical FRC bot.

Other hardwoods are likely to be stronger, heavier, and more expensive. My local lumber yard stocks 1x6 boards in Red Oak, Poplar, Cherry, Maple, SY Pine, and Nat. Birch. You can use the wood strength database to compare these. For bumpers you would probably care about the MOR index (how easy it is to break the board.)

Wood MOR Strength
Red Oak 35.4
Poplar 23.4 (yellow popular)
Cherry 29.6 (black cherry)
Maple 32.6 (red maple)
Nat. Birch 41.6 (yellow birch)

So if you were willing to spend more and have heavier bumpers, birch looks like a reasonable choice.

Solid wood can be okay if one is not going to install fasteners near any of the edges. It is easy to make it split, especially when shock forces are applied to the brackets attached to the wood. Depending on the type of wood, driving screws into it without pre-drilling a hole of the proper size may make it split.

If you are going to use solid wood, poplar is a good choice. It is stronger than clear pine and not much more expensive. It is also easier to work with, less likely to split, and less expensive than commonly available hardwoods like oak.

Honestly, now that the bumper rules have opened up, for a team that just wants good enough bumpers, my quick and easy recommendation would be locally available 1x6 (nominal) wood planks.

Pick something that will cut nicely with an oscillating saw with a plunge blade and a cutting blade with big teeth for wood. This is so much safer and easier than any kind of rotating saw, and for what amounts to a one-off afterthought project for a lot of teams, it’s the right level of unsophisticated.

With this, you can triangulate corners, or make brackets to fit the frame pretty much effortlessly. And mistakes are so cheap.


For fully-engineered bumpers, I have plenty of thoughts, mostly around plywood or even composites. (Someone is going to have a fully moulded carbon fibre bumper backing...and it will be great for them.) But it's just not worth it anymore, now that teams can throw precut wood at the | 8866 A | Manufacturing+Hardware","username":"Potatoes3","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/potatoes3/{size}/207513_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T23:36:50.609Z","cooked":"

As others have said there isn’t really a clear cut “best choice” for wood. Something our team learned over the past few years is that the support and fastening of the wood matters way more.

For example, interior corner brackets tend to bend overtime. Gaps between the chassis and wood backing can lead to damage upon impact. Small screws tend to pull out of most woods, Baltic birch and some others hold screws better but something going all the way through is likely the better option.

Our team experienced pretty bad deterioration, then we updated our mounting, support, etc and have seen significant improvement, without changing our wood type.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T23:36:50.609Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":39.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482895,"topic_slug":"best-bumper-wood","display_username":"David | 8866 A | Manufacturing+Hardware","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62171,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Cardboard enthusiast"},"post_url":"/t/best-bumper-wood/482895/11","custom_user_title":"Cardboard enthusiast","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3489636,"name":null,"username":"anon91718515","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/97f17d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-22T10:28:42.244Z","cooked":"

Howdy. This is a smart question, because you asked “given the circumstances”. Here’s my take on the circumstances.

  • This game is likely to have very few high speed collisions in the way the past two years did. This may have collision speeds more like 2022 or even slower, and you’re more likely to bounce off your alliance partners than either a ridid, narrow field object or an opponent.
  • The rules around bumper material have significantly relaxed. This includes not only backing material but also foam and cloth covers.

If you follow the advice given above mine, and use (for example) pine 1x6, you’re less likely to suffer debilitating damage to either your bumper or your robot than you would have been last year.

However,

The advice to use solid wood is based on a series of factual errors. The first is historical. There was never a time when plywood was required and solid wood was not allowed. Solid wood has always been allowed but it’s never been recommended.

The second error is the belief that solid wood is superior to plywood for this purpose. Speaking as someone who has been a woodworker and a woodworking teacher for the better part of half a century, this is absolutely not true. Solid wood, regardless of species, has strength along the grain but is weak perpendicular to this. Solid wood splits. Some splits less easily (Poplar) and some more so (Pine). It’s also inconsistent, because each piece has its own characteristics from the individual tree and part of the tree it was cut from.

Plywood reduces or eliminates these problems by taking taking multiple, thin sections of wood and turning them 90 degrees to each other multiple times. It is therefore more consistent in all directions, less prone to splitting, etc.

Baltic Birch and marine grade plywood are the gold standards for making structural elements like bumper backing. That said, they are expensive and hard to get. If you’re shopping at a big box store, the best choice is “sheathing” plywood, with a reasonably smooth and knot-free surface. This year, the thickness of your bumper backing isn’t going to be regulated, so if you can’t find 3/4" you’re not going to be in trouble, but thicker material is still a better choice than thinner. Worse choices than sheathing, from big box stores, in descending order are:

  • Treated plywood, which is heavier, wetter, and made to reduce decomposition in damp environments.
  • Finish grade plywood, with nice (but paper thin) wood on the surface. This costs a lot more and tends to flake apart unless cut very carefully with specialty sharp blades.
  • OSB, which is likely to flake or split.
  • Particle board, which has almost no tensile strength and will crumble.

Other quick notes:

  • Folks pointing out that 1x6 is cheap are right. If budget is super tight that’s about your least expensive option other than dumpster diving. Just being involved in a competition that costs $6000 to register for some events, however, makes me want to encourage you to carefully consider protecting your investment.
  • Whether using solid wood or plywood, attach your hardware with bolts and nuts that pass through the wood, rather than relying on screws into the wood itself, which tends to loosen or pull out over time when subject to the kinds of hits you will see in FRC.

Good luck, happy to help with any other questions about bumpers.

MrN

FRC is one of the few places students get to be actually hands on using all of sorts fabrication tools, if rotating saws are a safety hazard what is a CNC router or a lathe? If anyone is looking for saw recommendations, you can’t go wrong with a ryoba hand saw (get the ones with replaceable blades), in my experience it’ll be faster than an oscillating saw, with a better cut quality and no electricity needed. And a miter saw can be beaten for fast square cuts.

As for using solid wood, it is much worse at holding fasteners than a plywood of a similar species, but if you can use glued joints or bolts to clamp a large area of wood between two metal plates, some woods should be fine. Pine will still want to split if it’s not supported by the robot’s frame in a heavy collision, and the stuff sold as trim often has lots of finger joints that can be very weak.

I don’t think fully composite bumper backers would work very well, they’ll shatter if they’re much thinner than the wood would be, but they are much denser than wood.

mrnoble:

The advice to use solid wood is based on a series of factual errors. The first is historical. There was never a time when plywood was required and solid wood was not allowed. Solid wood has always been allowed but it’s never been recommended.

By way of history, there were early years where bumpers were optional (2005–2007), and starting in 2006, in exchange for having bumpers exempted from the overall size and/or weight, teams had to build a standard bumper design. That standard design required “plywood” to the absolute exclusion of all other forms of wood. Then from 2008, bumpers built to the standard design became mandatory, and plywood was therefore mandatory; this persisted from 2008–2012. In 2013, “solid, robust wood” became permissible. The definition of what was solid and/or robust was subject to interpretation, and various Q&As and inspectors have attempted to do so, differently in different years; sometimes the species or cut of wood was at issue.

mrnoble:

The second error is the belief that solid wood is superior to plywood for this purpose.

I agree that when people hold this belief, they are generally incorrect, in the sense that plywood is a superior product mechanically under almost all circumstances. I’m just saying that given the 2025 rules (both game and bumper), the margin of superiority isn’t what it used to be, and so if a team needs an easy way out, this could be it.

I definitely wouldn’t want teams to invest heavily in traditional finish woodworking skills, only to hit the limits of the base material. Now that non-wood backings are allowed, and that bumper weight itself is not constrained, teams who want to go all-in maybe ought not to even be using a wood product.

Patrick3357:

FRC is one of the few places students get to be actually hands on using all of sorts fabrication tools, if rotating saws are a safety hazard what is a CNC router or a lathe?

I agree with you that ideally, the use of those tools would be taught or learned properly, and that in those circumstances, they are reasonably safe for many common operations. I’m just saying that if the original poster is building the bumpers themself, as they supposed, it stands to reason that their individual capabilities might matter a lot. It might make sense to choose materials and tools that are less efficient, but which require less capital cost, less risk cost, less training and less permission.
